titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI:30.P. Little of H.R.U.S. here with Hamer of Baltimore. R. M. Johnson and J. T. Johnson came about R. C. Anderson, and how he is to go to Colombia, where he is appointed Minister. His outfit &c. W. LeeBall of H.R.U.S. came about Downman’s Slaves— at the Office, a succession of members of Congress. P. White of Vermont, with whom there was Doty of Michigan— He inquired about the judge to be appointed there by a new Law. Tomlinson of Connecticut to recommend a Consular applicant. Hamilton of S.C. to urge the nomination of T. Lee for District judge— Williamson and M. L. Hill of Maine, about the British Boundary, and the disagreement of the Commissioners under the 5th. Article of the Ghent Treaty. Hill also about the Hayti recognition and papers— Stewart of Pennsylvania and Parrott S.U.S. from New Hampshire recommendations for Consular Appointments. Eustis and Fuller visits for conversation—and Eustis for Roberts to be Consul— Menou came about the exchange of the Ratifications of the Convention with France of 24. June last. The Senate advised the ratification yesterday— Unanimously for the main Articles— All but 3 for the Separate Article— Frye and Mrs W. S. Smith here this Evening. John and Charles went to Rockville— I have a very bad Cold and Cough— Foot bath.

2. VII. Kept house the whole day, for my Cold and Cough which are very severe— R. Wright of Maryland called and took back the Letter he had lent me from James Roberts to him— Wright’s opinions on the slave trade favours yielding the right of search— Says it will raise the value of Slaves in Maryland— Miss Hopkinson arrived from Philadelphia. John and Charles back from Rockville— William Lee here this Evening—occupied answering interrogations in the case of Harris vs Lewis.

3. VII— Snowy morning. Ride to Branch and Metropolis Banks— At the Office. Note from P.U.S.— C. Pinkney—ready to return to St Petersburg. His accounts and claims— N. Knight S.U.S. from Rhode-Island with Pitman, and Dexter the Marshal— Supreme Court U.S. commence Session this day. Cabinet Meeting at 1/2 past one— All present but Wirt who is ill— Porto-Rico papers— Message from P.U.S. Draft. Crawford objects to sending some of the papers— Canning’s Slave-trade Note— Crawford comes out for yielding right of search—and Thompson—overruled— All but myself against the joint representation to France— Count de Menou’s wedding Ball, fireworks and illuminations— I remained at home for my Cold— Writing answers to interrogations— Rest of the family went to the Ball.

4. VII.W. D. Lewis here— His Commission from St. Petersburg has arrived at Boston— Mr Featherstonhaugh brought me a Letter from Hopkinson. Visit from L. Cheves— At the Office— Canning—read a despatch from G. Canning to Sir C. Stuart, about Cuba and Pirates— Colonial Intercourse Bill— Canning’s New Instructions— James Lloyd S.U.S. Letter from Boardman and Pope. Russian North-West Coast Ukaze— Told Lloyd the facts—not to be stated by him— Dined with Petry— Evening weekly and wedding party for the Bresson’s.

5— VII.James Barbour Chairman Comee. S.U.S. foreign Relations here. Colonial Intercourse Bill— His new objections and my answers. English Navigation Act of Charles 2. not repealed— Sent him Rush’s despatch and Robinson’s Speech. Dr Kent of Maryland here—in favour of W. G. D. Worthington. Talk about Presidential Election— Dispositions of Maryland— Of New-York— Sterling’s talk last Night. American— Went with Featherstonhaugh to P.U.S.—and two others again at P.U.S. alone— Told him of Canning’s despatch about Cuba— Bulfinch at the Office with Hall—professor of Middlebury College, Vermont— Fuller here after dinner. Smyth’s new publication in Democratic Press— Colvin’s false Statements— Violent Scene in H.R.U.S. this day. Eve at the Drawing-Room, Rest of the family did not go. Full Room.

6. VII.M. L. Hill here—invited me to dine with him to-morrow. At the Capitol. Meeting of Commissioners of the Sinking fund— All present, but Wirt— Business short— In the Senate— Met J. Taylor of Caroline— Heard debate in H.R.U.S. on the suppressed Document— Home to dine. Company. Brown of Louisiana, Clay, Dickerson, Bishop Dubourg of Louisiana, Durfee, Edwards of North Carolina, Findlay, Senator, Hernandez; Rowan and Son; and John Wells of Boston. The family went to an Evening party at T. Munroe’s. I did not go.

7. VI:15.W. D. Lewis here, with Letter from Jos. R. Ingersoll, and two Letters from L. Harris to C. Rodde—took part of my draft of Deposition— At the Office; Stevenson with Lambert applying for the Office of Consul at Vera-Cruz. Canning—Colonial Intercourse—Slave-trade— Asked him to let me shew the PresidentG. Canning’s despatch to Sir C Stuart about Cuba and the Pirates. Declines. Has no authority— Note to Menou— Dined with M. L. Hill— Speaker Barbour, the Maine Senators and B. Bassett there. Evening at the Ball at Mr Brown’s of Louisiana— Talk with J. C. Wright. Chess with Thruston.

8. VI.W. D. Lewis here. J. Bailey— Ingham for a Passport for Henry Troutman. At the Office, Stackelberg, about the total abolition of discriminating
duties with Norway. Wants an answer— Everett from P.U.S. for the papers recommending Doty as a judge for Michigan— Took them to P.U.S. He wrote to L. Harris, calling on him to return papers taken by him from the Department of State. Digest of Manufactures—Bristol County, Massachusetts omitted—other omissions. Marblehead present. A. Cod.— Eve at home, writing. Petry here.—did not see him.

9. VII. Heard Breckenridge— Joshua 22.20— And that man, perished not alone in his iniquity— Mahomet, Tom Paine, Hume and Voltaire. Wrote to B. Abbot, Exeter— No Church at Little’s P.M.— Call on Plumer; at Claxton’s. He will take T. Hellen with him— Call on Baylies at Coyle’s. Explained to him, the omission of Bristol County returns from that printed Digest of Manufactures. Visit to the Judges— Saw Chief Justice Marshall and Judge Johnson— The family passed the Evening at Mr Brown’s of Louisiana— J. W. Taylor there, P. B. Porter and Clay.— Letter from Fiske— Russell’s regrets and his proposed coalition between Clay and Crawford— Taylor recommends Conklin for District Attorney, Northern District of New-York.

10. VII:30.W. D. Lewis here. Barstow with Greenwood at Boston. Major Roberdeau with Mr Foster of Pennsylvania, and a Mr Alexander— At the Office— Menou left with me an answer to my Note—ready to Exchange Ratifications of the Convention. Prepared drafts of the Ratification and Proclamation. Evening Ball at Coll. Tayloe’s— The family went— I did not go. Commissioners to take my third Deposition in the case of Harris and Lewis, start at my house at 7. P.M. and sat till Midnight— Commissioners present on the part of Harris— Genl. J. P. Van Ness; and Coll. Henry Ashton—on the part of Lewis Captain Thomas Randall— R. Maury wrote for the Commissioners—who proceeded to the third Interrogatory on the part of Dept. When they adjourned to Wednesday Evening the 12th. at 7 in the Evening, again at my house— There was some small discussion, as to the Execution of the Commission.

11. VI:30.B. O. Tyler here— Metropolis Bank Shares for Sale— Letter from Harrisburgh, Pennsylvania— W. D. Lewis here— And G. Hay whom I did not see. At the Office, H. Niles of Baltimore, with Massey, applying for the Consulate of Lima— Menou to agree upon arrangements for executing the exchange of the Ratifications of the Convention of 24 June last. Letter to T. B. Wait. John and Charles missed this morning’s Stage— Weekly evening party. Say about 150. Dancing by the Piano. Dwight’s complaint against Walsh— Not many Members of Congress— Judge Bay of South-Carolina— Lawrence of New-York. S. Verplanck with Letter from J. P. De Wint.

12. VI.John and Charles went in the Stage—returning to Cambridge— B. O. Tyler here—pamphlets— Gilmer—application for pay for a revenue Officer at Pensacola— To speak with Mr Crawford about it. At the Office. Mr. C. J. Ingersoll called to borrow books from the Library of the Department. Captain O’Brien about his Accounts. I am not ready to report in his case. He says he can only dig a cellar now, to build, next Session— Lincoln came to recommend Conklin— So had Tracy yesterday— Menou with Bresson. Exchanged the Ratifications of the Convention of 24 June last, executed certificates of Exchange. Delivered Menou two Declarations— Evening second Meeting of Commissioners, to take my Deposition, at my house— Genl. J. P. Van Ness, and G. M. Dallas, Commissioners for Plf— Captain T. Randall for Deft.R. Maury as Clerk— Coll. Ashton did not attend— All of the Monday’s work useless— My answers to be delivered only and not read— Sworn again—and R. Maury sworn as Clerk— Adjourned between 10 and 11—to meet here again Friday Evening at 7.— My cough subsiding.

13. VII:30.R. Little called with a Prospectus for a scientific periodical work, W. D. Lewis with a Letter from Jos. R. Ingersoll— Mode of taking my deposition— At the Office, Mr Gamble about Land-Claims in Florida. His Son and his Uncle— Boardman—Senator U.S. and his Son. Call from W. Smith Chairman of Judiciary Committee Senate U.S. for recommendations of T. Lee of District judge S.C— Took them to P.U.S. His doubts about sending them to the Comee. desired me to see Calhoun. C. J. Ingersoll at P.U.S.— Company to dine— Judge Bay, Burton, Chambers, J. Holmes, C. J. Ingersoll, E. Ingersoll, F. Johnson, Mercer, Pierson, Stevenson, Talbot— Mrs Adams unwell. No Ladies at table. Eve at Calhoun’s Ball, with George. Spoke to Calhoun for the Call for recommendations of T. Lee. Chess with Harper.

14. VII:W. D. Lewis here this morning. At the Office— A Strange man there by name of Wing. Papers relating to the Convention of 1818 sent to H.R.U.S— At P.U.S—with draft of Bill to carry into effect the Convention with France of 24. June last, and of Letters to A. Gallatin. Evening at home— Commissioners to take my deposition in the case of L. Harris versus W. D. Lewis here from 7—P.M. to near midnight. J. P. Van Ness, Coll. Ashton, G. M. Dallas— T. Randall, and R. Maury as Clerk. Coll. Ashton came late, and Dallas went away early. Dallas’s objections to receiving as exhibits the Letters from the Seamen of the Monticello, Petry here, above— Stormy day.

15. VII.15.Morgan of H.R.U.S. here. Enquiries about the appointment of Henry Austin and R. Hunter as Consuls. Asks also for the papers of Gerard D. Smith— W. D. Lewis also here— Fuller at the Office, brother to the member of the House— And G. Blake— Long conversation with him— Talks as if he was zealous— The day wasted— Evening from 7 to near Midnight, Commissioners to take my Deposition in the case of Harris and Lewis here— Dallas, Ashton, and T. Randall, with R. Maury as Clerk— Made some progress— Offered Extracts from my Diary—excepted against, but received. Bishop Dubourg was above, but I did not see him— Miss Hopkinson went to Mr Brown’s of Louisiana.

16. VII. Heard Little at the Capitol. Philippians 2.15.— Among whom shine ye as lights in the world— Call on J. Sergeant, and on D: P. Cook— Objection in H.R. to printing the Convention of 1818 documents— Laborie here. P.M. heard Baldwin at Baker’s— Philippians 2.12. I believe— Work out your own salvation with fear and trembling— Sermon begun before we went in— Mrs. Adams and the family passed the Evening at W. S. Smith’s. I at home, writing.

17. VII— MrMathews the Roman Catholic Clergyman here—dispute with the Archbishops about Lands— D. P. Cook here— Colonial Intercourse Act— Illinois appointments— Crawford and P.U.S— At the Office. M’Lane, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means H.R.U.S— Appropriation for the Russian Convention— Sent him an estimate— Moore of Alabama— Passport and Letter for Baldwin— Mobile Argus to print the Laws— Ramsay, and his claim—another defective voucher— Bulfinch with Coolidge from Boston— Parish with an unsigned Note from Canning. Colonial Intercourse— Tracy from Connecticut, claimant, under the Florida Treaty. Charles Ruggles of H.R.U.S. to recommend Conklin— District Attorney. Northern District of N. York— Received Sutherland’s resignation— Fuller here, after dinner— Commissioners in the case of Harris vs Lewis— Van Ness, Dallas, T. Randall, and as Clerk, R. Maury— Made progress, and adjourned to Friday Evening. Ball at Mr Brown’s of Louisiana— Mrs Adams and the family attended.

18. VII.J. C. Wright and Sloan of Ohio— Wright gave me his resignation as District Attorney, in Ohio, after 3. March— Recommends Beebe. Sloan— Tappan— Hammond a Candidate— Eddy of Rhode-Island here; to recommend young Robbins. W. D. Lewis, with Letter from Todd, the sometime Supercargo of the ship Dispatch. At the Office, Dr. Everitt the President’s
private Secretary, about the nomination of Coxe to the Legislative Council in Florida— Stackelberg about the abolition of discriminating duties with Norway— O’Brien for his claim— James G. Forbes, about the failure of his nomination and his claim— Mr Lee with Mr Lynch, a member of the Legislature of New-York, and candidate for Office of District Attorney— Conklin, a Candidate for the same place; and Laborie to take leave— Going to-morrow for New-York, to embark for France— At the President’s— Left with him the Note from Mr Canning, against an Act of South-Carolina— C. Pinkney’s claim as Messenger to be allowed— Weekly evening party—About 150. Numerous Strangers— Members of Congress not many— Dancing.

19. VII.D. P. Cook here, about the Colonial intercourse Bill— At the Office. Drury from Rhode-Island— Talks politics— Charles Pinkney— His Charge as Messenger allowed— Frye— Asks to be introduced to Canning— I said I would next Tuesday at my House— Captain Riley from Ohio. Talks politics— Evening at the Drawing Room—

20. VII. At the Office— Answering Calls— Report on the Catalogue of Books, and Newspapers taken at the Office— Answer to James Barbour on O’Brien’s petition— Sent him also the Nootka Sound Treaty between Spain and Great Britain— We had company to dine, Baylies, CoolidgeH. W. Edwards of Cont.Fuller, H. Johnson, F. Gray, James Lloyd, LowrieSibley, Trimble, Upham, T. H. Williams, L. Williams, and Wood. also Miss Hopkinson— Evening at Coll. Henderson’s Ball— Editorial Article in Frankfort Kentucky Argus of 6. February.

21. VII.D. Brent here, about the nominations to Offices— Calhoun at the Office—recommending Benham as District Attorney for Ohio. At P.U.S. who was gone out— Left Forsyth’s despatch, decyphered at his house. Ball at Crawford’s— The rest of the family went— I was at home, attending the Meeting of the Commissioners to take my deposition, in the case of Harris vs. Lewis— Randall, Dallas and Genl. Van Ness attended with R. Maury— Made progress to the ninth Cross-Interrogatory. Adjourned, near Midnight, to meet to-morrow Evening at 7.

22. VII: Received at the Office a Note from P.U.S. calling a Cabinet Meeting on the St. Domingo papers.— J. Holmes’s call— S.U.S. I attended— Crawford, Calhoun and Thompson present— Wirt absent— A perplexing subject. Inginac’s Letter. Boyer’s proclamation— Haytian Constitution— Opinions
all mysterious— No decision— Forsyth’s cyphered despatch read. H. Johnson at the Office, with a revived claim of R. Kemper; to be examined— Report of Commissioners on the 6th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent. 23 Maps. Evening. Mr and Mrs Frye here; Went with Mrs Adams and the family today Washington Birth-Night Ball— I did not go— J. Rhea here with Letters from S. Kingston—claims on Spain— To see him again on Monday— Commissioners here to take my deposition—in the case of Harris vs Lewis— Randall, Van Ness and Dallas were here—and R. Maury as Clerk. They finished taking my Answers— And adjourned to Monday Morning ten O’Clock to take Gales’s— Miss Hopkinson came from the ball with Mrs Adams.

23. VII.Captain Ridgeley of U.S. Navy here. Called the request of P.U.S. His account of Eldridge in Chili and Peru, unfavorable— Eldridge will not be nominated as Consul at Lima. Heard Little. A.M. from Ephesians 5.—8–11. Negative duties of Christians— Called and saw H. L. White and W. King—left Card for L. W. Tazewell— Called on Newton, the Chairman of Comee. of Commerce H.R.U.S— Talk with him of the Norway regulation— Of the French Convention Bill— Of the British Colonial intercourse Bill— To send him the papers relating to the last, to-morrow morning. Heard Little again P.M. 1. Corinthians 10.12–13. “Wherefore let him that thinketh he standeth, take heed lest he fall— There hath no temptation taken you, but such as is common to man.[”]— Memento— The family spent the Evening at W. S. Smith’s— I at home; reading Tudor’s life of Otis, and writing.

24. VI:30.R. M. Johnson here S.U.S.— Surveyor at Portland— Smith, Boyd, and W. Storer— D. Brent, about nominations. J. Rhea, upon Stephen Kingston’s claims— A. Binney, Navy Agent at Boston. R. M. Johnson again, with Lincoln of Boston and Hill of Connecticut— At the Office— Jennings of Indiana, H.R.U.S., about Huffman’s claim for payment of his expenses— Referred to the Department of War— Took the papers— Dodge the Consul at Marseilles. Wishes continued leave of absence through the next Summer. M’Lean, Commissioner of Land-Office, to urge appointment of Benham as District Attorney for Ohio. His objections to Tappan— Eldridge—pressing for his nomination as Consul at Lima. At P.U.S. with all the nominations to be made— He is not ready. Surveyor at Portland— Smith— W. Storer— Boyd. Evening at Wirt’s Ball. Chess with E Ingersoll— Apollon— Spoke to J. Holmes for an Appropriation.

25. VII.E. A. Brown of Senate U.S. was here about the appointment of a District Attorney in Ohio; he knows not whom of the numerous candidates to recommend— W. D. Lewis with Letter from Jos. R. Ingersoll. New efforts of Harris’s Counsel to exclude testimony— At the Office— Ekins came as a Candidate for a Clerk’s Office— T. Fuller upon various business in the House— Porto-Rico and Cuba Pirates— Captain Riley— Meeting of Connecticut and Ohio Delegations last Evening. R. J. Meigs— Riley a Sangwine man, and a Traveller— Weekly Evening party. — About 150. Many Strangers. H.R. in Evening Session—few members here— Letters from Wait and B. Abbot.

26. VI:30.Gould at the Office, about his Account for books furnished the Department. Agreed to leave it to Mr Southard— G. B. English, with a Letter from H. A. S. Dearborn, his wish to be employed in Turkey— To see the President. Call at the Treasury— Crawford engaged— At P.U.S. about the nominations Still postponed— C. Pinkney dined with us— Evening Ball and Supper, at Secretary Thompson’s— Home near Midnight.

27. VII.Mr L. Rice of the Columbian College, introduced Baptist Clergyman, named Andrew Sherburne, residing at Columbus Ohio, now from Maine. Then came Mr Southard with Gould, about his Bill for Books. Next Mr Poinsett with Barrientos from Colombia—and afterwards D. Brent with Gouverneur about nominations to the Senate— At the Office, came Mr D’Arcy of Baltimore, applying to be Consul at Jamaica— MrM’Kim, with Bose one of the Editors of the American at Baltimore, and Mr Tracy of Connecticut, an applicant under the Florida Treaty— At P.U.S. with note from Anduaga complaining against Captain Wilkinson of the Spark. Company to dine Barrientos, Cheney, Eaton, Everitt, Gouverneur, Poinsett, and Ruggles. Seventeen Members of Congress failed, both Houses holding Evening Sessions— At the Ball at Commodore Chauncey’s— Chess with Dr Tucker. Miss Hopkinson did not go.

28. VI:45. A Mr Danforth of Tennessee, originally of Billerica, Massachusetts here, to borrow the Tennessee Laws— Has a cause for trial in the Supreme Court— Talk about Presidential election— Boardman S.U.S. Connecticut and Ohio— Internal improvement and domestic manufactures. Party principles and Presidential Election. Fuller— His Resolution concerning Porto-Rico privateers— Eldredge— Objections to his nomination as Consul at Lima— Garnett— Anti-manufacturing doctrines, and discontent— At P.U.S. Everitt, and Eldredge at the Office— Eldredge’s Disappointment. Eve at Canning’s Ball. — Chess with Dr Tucker and Mrs Roberdeau— Cheney dined with us.
